text: Anybody here using an ARM desktop? It occurs to me that I've only owned laptops all my life, and the pandemic is a great opportunity for me to switch to more hackable desktops. And switching to ARM may reduce the energy barrier for later forking Mu to it.

elements.text: Anybody here using an ARM desktop? It occurs to me that I've only owned laptops all my life, and the pandemic is a great opportunity for me to switch to more hackable desktops. And switching to ARM may reduce the energy barrier for later forking Mu to it.

text:
A Raspberry Pi 4 seems perfect for this, though I admit I haven't taken the leap to use one as my daily driver.
I have been eyeing the <https://pine64.com/product/14%E2%80%B3-pinebook-pro-linux-laptop-ansi-us-keyboard/?v=0446c16e2e66|Pinebook Pro> for a while, but they sell out very quickly!

I have been eyeing the
for a while, but they sell out very quickly!

text: Emphasis on desktop. They just seem intrinsically more open and moddable. But yes, RPi was on my mind in considering ARM.

elements.text: Emphasis on desktop. They just seem intrinsically more open and moddable. But yes, RPi was on my mind in considering ARM.

text:
I just realized that! Sorry! That's what I get for reading too fast and jumping to comment. :flushed:

I don't know of many classical desktop tower setups that are ARM based in the consumer space. I think Huawei was releasing one for the Chinese market recently?

ARM is a bit niche in the classical desktop market unfortunately. x86 seems to have a monopoly there... The motherboard manufacturers don't have any incentive to make ARM compatible desktop boards.

There is the new Apple Desktop ARM machines that are coming soon, but something tells me that is not what you had in mind in terms of openness or moddability.

text: Yeah exactly. I'd rather stick with a laptop than buy another Apple. I'm done with them (though I have to continue to use employer-provided Macs).

elements.text: Yeah exactly. I'd rather stick with a laptop than buy another Apple. I'm done with them (though I have to continue to use employer-provided Macs).

text: The RPi400 looks cool (the one that's built into a keyboard). It still has the GPIO pins exposed to allow for some potentially cool hackability.
